thread.title: LMU basketball staff is complete - News Sentinel
thread.title_full: LMU basketball staff is complete - News Sentinel Story

author: News Sentinel staff
title: LMU basketball staff is complete - News Sentinel
text:
Lincoln Memorial University has promoted Davis Fisher to lead assistant, Omar Wattad to full-time assistant and has hired Ben Thompson as an assistant coach to its men's basketball staff.
Fisher's promotion comes after Cameron Whicker's transition to assistant athletic director at LMU.
Fisher is entering his third season at LMU and second as a full-time assistant coach.
Wattad was a high school standout at Science Hill. He signed with Georgetown and, after two years as a reserve, transferred to Chattanooga, where he was a prolific 3-point scorer. After graduating in 2012, Wattad had professional stints in the Republic of Georgia and Israel before joining the Railsplitters as a graduate assistant a year ago.
Thompson, a 2006 graduate of Virginia Tech, spent last season at Virginia Military Institute and previous to that was an assistant coach at UNC Pembroke for three seasons.
Thompson was video coordinator and assistant to the head coach at Virginia Tech in 2010, an assistant coach at Saint Leo College in 2009, director of basketball operations at UNC Greensboro in 2008 and a graduate assistant at Virginia Tech from 2006-08.
Meanwhile, Terrance Birdette will be joining the staff as a graduate assistant coach. A 2012 graduate of Elon University and former player there, Birdette spent the last couple of years in corporate sales.
Jeremiah Samarrippas returns for his second season as a graduate assistant.
"I am excited to have Davis, Omar and Jeremiah back in the fold," LMU coach Josh Schertz said in a school release. "All three are outstanding young coaches and their return gives us an increased level of corporate knowledge on the sidelines which is invaluable."
Baseball Staff: LMU added Josh Epstein as pitching coach and Justin Haywood as full-time assistants on the baseball team.
Epstein spent the past two seasons as pitching coach for Bloomsburg (Pa.). He previously was pitching coach at Ramapo College of New Jersey.
Haywood was a graduate assistant the past two seasons for the Railsplitters. He will work with hitters and catchers. Haywood, a former catcher at Louisville, previously was an assistant for two seasons at Marist College and spent one season as a volunteer assistant coach at Old Dominion.
